text:

from hundreds of MIT courses,
visit MIT OpenCourseWare at ocw.mit.edu.

PROFESSOR: Today we'll
talk about asymmetric tops.

And I discovered that there
are a lot of mistakes that still exist in these notes. And I'll try to correct them.

A lot of the material in these
lectures comes from this book

by Townes and Schawlow. I have a four book
rule, that there

are certain books which are
sufficiently important that you have to have four copies,
one for the office,

one for the lab, one for the
bathroom, and one for your bed.

And Townes and Schawlow
is a four booker.

There are a few others that
have to be a four book class.

Like Tinkham used to
be for me and certainly

Herzberg's Diatomics. But this is by far and away the
most important book you could

have in your library, I think. AUDIENCE: Well, other
than [INAUDIBLE]..
PROFESSOR: That's up for-- you can decide.

AUDIENCE: Are there three
bookers and two bookers as well? PROFESSOR: Absolutely. And there are negative ones.

I mean, books that you have
to have, but you don't want.

AUDIENCE: What was the last
place of the four books? Office, lab-- PROFESSOR: Bathroom and bed.

AUDIENCE: OK. PROFESSOR: You've got to have
something under your pillow.

OK, so it's been a long time
since I've assigned a problem.

And so I have one today. And this is kind of
a classic problem.

And we're just
about at the point where you can do this one. And it also helps
to ameliorate some

of the incredible stupidity
I did last lecture. OK, consider the molecule, SF4.

SF4 was a classic molecule
in testing qualitative ideas

of molecular structure.  And in fact, there is
a paper by John Waugh

in which he puts his
decisive two cents
in to deciding the structure. So what I want you to do--

now, some of you have had a
connection with 5.11 1 or 2.

And Vesper is taught,
or used to be taught-- is Vesper taught in
5.11 1 or 5.11 2?

AUDIENCE: It's mentioned. PROFESSOR: Well, if you use
valence shell electron pair repulsion, you can predict the
correct qualitative structure

of SF4. So what I want you
to do is to calculate the microwave spectrum for J.
So for all transitions with J

equal to or smaller than
4, in other words 4 to 3,
assuming tetrahedral structure.

That's easy, right. I mean, I didn't want to say
it, but the D3H structure, D3H

is a symmetry point group. It's analogous to
ammonia, except it's

got an extra fluorine,
and the teeter totter structure, which is--

AUDIENCE: That's the
technical term for it. AUDIENCE: The technical term
is seesaw, but whatever. PROFESSOR: Oh,
seesaw, OK, right.

So you have a base of one
SF2 and then the two others

with longer bonds
and nearly linear. That's the correct structure.

And so if you calculate
the microwave spectra

for these three
species, you will get a sense of how you could
use microwave spectroscopy

to decide, what is
the structure of SF4? Now, what I want you to do
is to make reasonable guesses

for bond lengths. And I don't care what
reasonable guesses you use.

One thing you could do is take
the bond length, the SF bond
length, from SF6.

Or you could just guess
a reasonable bond length based on information in the old
chemical [INAUDIBLE] tables,

where they gave the radii,
the covalent radii, of atoms,

but whatever. However you decide, I want you
to calculate the structure. I actually used to give
an exam, where I would

give the microwave spectrum. And you would have to assign
it and deduce a structure.

And so the main reason
for giving such a problem

is when you're faced with
the microwave spectrum, you start out by
assuming a geometry,

locating the center mass,
and then either by inspection

figuring out which are
the A, B, and C axes. Or you just write the inertial
tensor and diagonalize it.

And I guarantee you that for
the teeter totter geometry,

or the seesaw geometry,
whatever you want to call it,

you're not going to find-- well, that's actually not true. There's enough symmetry that
you can simplify the problem,

so that at least you don't
have to diagonalize a 3 by 3.

So that's a problem. And let's have that
done a week from Friday.

OK, so-- we want to set up
the effective Hamiltonian,

or the Hamiltonian,
for an asymmetric top. And we start out
by knowing the way

to set up the
rotational Hamiltonian for a symmetric top. And so let's just
review some of that.

We have something here, which
we will just call J. Now,

this strictly isn't J. It's J
minus orbital angular momentum

minus spin minus vibrational
angular momentum.

So this is basically the nuclear
rotation excluding vibration.

And there is this wonderful
classic paper by Watson, 1968.

I was a graduate student then. And this is really the
rotational Hamiltonian.

It's also called the Watsonian. It's so important that instead
of calling it a Hamiltonian,

it's called the Watsonian. And that's really a tribute
from your colleagues

to have something
named after you. OK, so anyway, we
want this thing.

And if you can find the
coordinate system in which

the inertial tensor
is diagonal, then you
can write the Hamiltonian--

like this. So we have three
rotational constants.

Now, by definition, the moments
of inertia, IA, IB, and IC,

this is the light one. And so the rotational constants
are always in this order.

Now, this is actually
quite important. Because the masses,
the moments of inertia,

are something that are
absolutely knowable. And we're going to be observing
small splittings when we start

dealing with asymmetric tops. And these small splittings,
asymmetry doublings,

have a sign. And that sign is determined
by the inertias, the moments

of inertia, and the symmetry. And so in an
electronic transition,

knowing the moments of
inertia and the energy order

to asymmetry split
levels, you can often determine the electronic
vibrational symmetry

of a state. And that's actually a
really important thing. It's one of those invariant
things that you can use.

It's not an accident. Often, when you have
small doublings, it's due to an accident.

It's due to second
order effects. This is not. This is really something
you can depend on.

And it's neglected. OK, so now, these
moments of inertia,

despite what is
written in the notes, are the sum of the masses times
the square of the perpendicular

distance from the
appropriate axis. And so if we were to look
at a molecule like this,

and first of all,
for that shape,

this is cisbent acetylene,
in case you didn't--

then no, it's in
the C2V point group. But now, we have three
different ways of labeling axes.

We have A, B, and C. We have
X, Y, and Z based on symmetry.

And we have Z based
on near symmetry.
And it's very confusing.

And sometimes when you
have two different forms of the molecules, these
are both C2V molecules.

The near symmetry
axis is this and that.

AUDIENCE: What exactly is
meant by near symmetry?

PROFESSOR: Well, these
are both prolate tops. And the prolate axis is
the near symmetry axis.

It's the A axis.  But from a group
theoretical point of view,

that's the z-axis. This is the z-axis. So we have the z-axis
determined two different ways.

And then we have
A, B, and C, which are determined by
moments of inertia.

OK, so there's a lot of
hidden complexity in this.

OK, now, one of the things
that you want to be able to do is to develop some
intuition for how

do A, B, and C change as
the molecule is distorted

through various normal
mode vibrations?

Because one of the
things that you often use to make vibrational
assignments--

now, I'm talking
about normal modes. We haven't done normal
modes in this class. But everybody knows what
a vibration is and has

some ideas about normal modes. So how the A, B,
and C rotational

constants change with
vibrational excitation or how they are different
from those in the ground

vibrational state provide a clue
as to the vibrational nature of the state. And so you don't need to
have all the machinery

of writing down the center
of mass coordinate system

and going to the
coordinate system, where the inertial tensor is diagonal.

You can do a lot of that
stuff in your heads. And you should practice that.

And there are some
wonderful things. I mean, suppose we start-- OK, so for this molecule,
I've already told you

the a-axis is like this. Because this axis
puts the heavy atoms

close to the axis and all the
atoms as close to the axis as possible. You want the smallest
moment of inertia.

And so then there's
the question, is this the b-axis
or the c-axis?

The center of mass is
somewhere about there.

And so is this C? Or is that C? And so if we have an axis
here, the perpendicular
distances of-- well, we can look--

basically, if you look
only at the heavy atoms,

then you can see that the
heavy atoms are farther from-- the perpendicular to this axis
is longer to the heavy atoms

then from here. And so that already
gives you some guidance.

If you have a longer distance,
the moment of inertia is larger. And that makes it the c-axis.

AUDIENCE: Is it always
true for planar molecules

that the c-axis is out-of-plane? PROFESSOR: Yes. And so is that something
that you've heard, memorized,

or thought through? AUDIENCE: I thought that
I had heard it before. I was trying to remember it.

PROFESSOR: Yeah, I mean,
most people have heard that. It's familiar. And it's an easy
fact to remember.

If you've got a planar
molecule, c-axis is perpendicular to plane.

But you ought to convince
yourself that it's true. It's not too hard.

OK, one of the things that
I like to challenge you with is suppose you start with
a molecule that's planar

and you do a torsion.  Well, what's going to happen
is that the B and C axes,

the B and C moments of inertia. So as you do a torsion away
from the cisbent geometry,
the symmetry axis doesn't move. You still have a C2 axis.

But as you do this torsion,
the B and C axes switch roles.

You get an accidental
symmetric top at some angle, which is
something that the acetylene

people have experienced. And you can also
do that starting

from the transbent geometry. And so the interesting
question is,

suppose you have
a vibration, which has large enough amplitude
that at one turning point,

the B and C axes
have one orientation,

and at the other turning
point, the B and C

axes have switched roles. And surely there's going
to be complexity there.

Then there's the issue of in
order to describe rotation,

we think about the
molecules being rigid.

And we solve this
problem when we find the special
coordinate system, where the inertial tensor is diagonal.

Well, what happens when
the molecule vibrates?

Is the inertial tensor
going to stay diagonal? What do we mean by the body
fixed coordinate system?

I mean, we establish this
special coordinate system

by saying, OK, the atoms
have definite locations. But what if they're moving?

Are we going to establish
a coordinate system, which

is based on where they
were when they started? Or are you going to follow?

And if the atoms move, do you
define a coordinate system

where the inertial tensor
is always diagonal? If that's true, then
the coordinate system is going to be doing that,
which is not inertial,

which leads to all
sorts of problems. Now, you can do
whatever you want.

But you have to be honest. If you've created
a problem, you're going to have to use
your basis functions

to solve the problem later. But as soon as you go away
from diatomic molecules,

you really have to
understand the physics. You have to be
able to understand

all of the subtle effects. And one of the things
that's so tempting

to do when we're dealing
with matrix mechanics is to pretend that we
understand everything.

And so you have to be careful. OK, so we're going to talk
about asymmetric top starting

from what we know
about symmetric tops.

And Sam asked the
question at the end of the last lecture, which
led me to draw a correlation diagram on the board.

And that's really
where we want to start.
So we have a prolate and oblate.

And I did this for j equals 2. So let's do it again
for j equals 2.
And so we have a level here. And we have a level here.

And in the prolate top, well,
the energy levels go as b or jj

plus 1 plus a quantity
a minus b a squared.

And over here, it's b jj plus
1 plus c minus b k squared.

This is negative. This is positive. And so we had energy levels
like this and like that.

This is positive and large. This is negative and small. Now, you can have
positive and negative Ks.

And so these
levels-- so 0, 1, 2-- these are doubled.
And 0, 1, and 2--

the doubling in the symmetric
top, this is a parity doubling.

Parity is something
that commutes with the full Hamiltonian.

But it also commutes with
the rotational Hamiltonian. It doesn't matter what the
shape of the molecule is. It doesn't matter whether
it's symmetric top

or an asymmetric top. You can show that there's
going to be a good quantum

number called parity. It comes from sigma
v. And but now, we

have a non-crossing rule. And so we start with the
unique level, which we

could call it positive parity. But it doesn't really matter. The unique level correlates to
one of these k equals 2 levels.

These two levels are degenerate. The level here has
a definite parity. It joins up with a level
of its same parity.

The other parity level
correlates with this.

And so no assumptions
are being made. And we just continue
connecting levels

until we run out of levels. And you might as well
draw straight lines.

Now, we have a Hamiltonian. It will tell us what
the form will be. But it's reasonable to expect
that as you break the symmetry,

you're not going to get some
kind of a crazy behavior, where these levels of
opposite parity will cross.

That's legal.  But levels of the same
parity can't cross.

And so it's reasonable to
expect that this correlation diagram with straight
lines across from these two

qualitatively different patterns
will give a good idea of what

the energy levels look like
as you get starting to go away from symmetric top limit.

And so a huge amount
of insight can

be obtained by simply
drawing these vertical lines. Now, what you'd really
like is some way

of being quantitative
about where you are between the prolate
limit or the oblate limit.

And we're going to
talk about that. And there's no reason
to rely on this diagram

when you could simply
calculate everything. However, a huge amount
of qualitative insight

is obtained from this diagram. And in fact, we label states
according to this diagram.
So we label energy levels.

Now, in Townes and Schawlow's
book, instead of ka kc,

it was k minus 1 k1. The reason for that
is this suggests

that these are the
projections of j on the a-axis

and on the c-axis, which
is only half correct.

What you'll
discover-- well, what you can see is when you
make this correlation,

you have a near prolate top. You have definite KAs. Those are, in fact,
the projection

of J on inertial axes. And you have two
levels of the same ka

And they correlate to
levels of different KC. That's just a label.

Why only two? Well, it's only two,
because it's not really

a projection on the c-axis. It's just the two
possible states that a particular value
of ka can correlate to.

So Townes and Schawlow use
this kind of neutral notation to avoid suggesting something
that wasn't completely true.

And there's another
notation, Tau. Tau goes from minus j to plus j.

There are two j plus 1
possible values of tau. This is also something
that's absolutely true.
It's the energy rank. You have this diagram. You count up from the bottom.

And so any particular
molecule, you can label levels without any ambiguity just
saying, this is the lowest

and this is the highest. And you know how many
possible levels there are. And so if I give you
a state 4 minus 2,

you know pretty much where
that is in the level diagram. It's much nicer to know 4 minus
2 in terms of ka kc labels.

OK, so there's all of
these different labels. And almost everyone
uses this notation.

But this j tau notation is
a really good notation too.

And you want to be careful. If you're near
the prolate limit,

the first index
is a good measure of the projection on
the near symmetry axis.

If you're near the oblate
limit, the second index is really a projection
[INAUDIBLE] over.

And the other is just a label. Now, studying of
this you discover

that ka plus kc can be
equal to j or jay plus 1.

Those are the only two
possible values for ka plus kc.

And you can also
convince yourself whether this one or this
one is always higher.

OK, and the higher one, the
higher energy level, let's say,

for this goes to the
lower value of kc.

So that means that the higher
of the two asymmetry components

is always the one where
ka plus kc sums to j. The lower one is
always j plus 1.

There are other
qualitative things that you can get from this.

If this diagram were drawn
reasonably correctly,

you would be able to
see that the splitting--

you would see that the
splitting in low k levels is larger than the
splitting in high k levels,

despite what the
spastic did up here.

And why is that? Because the higher k
levels are connecting to Ks that have smaller
splitting over here.

So there's a huge amount
you get from this diagram and from this labeling system.

And I'm spending a
lot of time doing really simple-minded stuff.

But it's really
important to realize how beautiful and powerful
just the notation is. Barrett?

AUDIENCE: Why did you say that
the oblate levels are closer together?

PROFESSOR: Because a is
bigger than b bigger than c. And so the prolate, you have the
big thing minus a medium size

thing. AUDIENCE: So if one is big,
than the other is small? PROFESSOR: That's right. AUDIENCE: OK.

It's just because
of their signs. PROFESSOR: Well, there's a sign. Both of them have a difference.

But one is up like this. And the other is like that. But also there's one like
this and one like that.

OK? AUDIENCE: It was really bad,
but you can do the same thing.

PROFESSOR: You could
cook up a situation. But it's generally true
that a is much bigger
than b in an absolute sense.

And for the same
percentage difference, the difference between
b and c would be really
small in an absolute sense. And that's the way it works.

So what else did I
want to say about that? Let's begin again and
derive the Hamiltonian

for an asymmetric top
starting from having gotten

to the diagonal representation. So we have rotation
is given by jx

squared over 2ix plus jy
squared over 2iy plus jz squared

over 2iz.  And so we know always jz
squared on jkm is going to be hr
squared k squared jkm.

And j squared, we know
what j squared does. We know what j plus minus do.

And the only caution is j
plus is a lowering operator. And j minus is a
raising operator.

Because this is a raising
and lowering operator

in the rotating frame. And we always reverse the sense. And so we need to do a
little bit of algebra.

So jx, well, we define raising
and lowering operators.

And so we can write jx as
1/2 j plus plus j minus.

And we can define jy as
minus i over 2 times j plus
minus j minus.

That's true. All of that's true. OK, so now, what
we'd like to do is

use these relationships
between Cartesian components

and raising and lowering
components to calculate the terms that go in here. So jx squared is
going to be 1/4.

j plus squared plus j
minus squared plus j plus j
minus plus j minus j plus.

And jy squared is going to be
minus 1/4 j plus squared plus j
minus squared plus j plus.

OK, where is it? Minus, there we go. Minus j plus j minus
minus j minus j plus.

OK? So we're going to take
advantage of the fact

that we have jx
squared and jy squared having off diagonal terms that
have exactly the same form

and having these terms,
which have opposite sides.
Let's see if I got that right.
Where did I do this?

OK, we do a little bit
more algebra though. j plus j minus plus
j minus j plus,

if we multiply that out,
we discover that this

is 2jx squared plus jy squared,
which is just 2j squared

minus jz squared.  So we have these terms
turn out to be diagonal.

These terms turn out
to be off diagonal. And we can start
combining things.

So what we do since we have
diagonal terms for jx squared

and jy squared that have the
same value, but opposite sign,

we can write the diagonal
part of the Hamiltonian, where we place jx squared by
2j squared minus jz squared.

And so we multiply
by 1 over 2 ix.

And now the jy squared
has the same thing, but with a minus sign.
And how did I do it wrong? It looks like I did.
What have I done?

OK, I've got some
signs reversed.  These are supposed to
have the same sign.

All right, let's
just go back up here.
OK, jx squared is--

so jx is that. So we're going to
get jx squared.

That's going to be j plus
squared and j minus squared

and then plus j plus j minus
and the other way around.

And jy squared is
going to give us--

oh, there it is. OK, so we had a minus
sign out in front. And it cancels it.

So we had a minus sign out
here, because i squared.

So the notes are
correct on this. And then there is also
a jz squared term.

And so we have jx
squared over 2iz.

So this is the diagonal part
of the rotational Hamiltonian.

And then the off diagonal part
of the rotational Hamiltonian, we had these terms with j
plus squared j minus squared.

So 1/4 and minus 1/4. And so we get 1/4 j plus squared
plus j minus squared times 1
over 2ix plus 1 over 2 by y.

And now I got the
signs reversed. OK, this is correct.

OK, so diagonal term, we have
a sum of rotational constants.

And this looks
very much like what we had for the symmetric top.

It is what we had for
the symmetric top. It was derived differently.

And here is something new. And these are matrix elements
that cause change in k by 2.

Now, we know what
j plus on jkm does. And j plus squared on
jkm does that twice.

So we know all the
matrix elements. And so we now have the
form of the Hamiltonian.

And we can write
this Hamiltonian in either of two limits,
or actually, three limits.

The near prolate limit
then what we're doing

is we're building our model
of how the levels behave based on the prolate symmetric top.

So we would like to
describe the perturbation

term as something that's small. And so we're going to be
interested in b minus c.

We're going to call these two
rotational constants b and c.

There's a difference
in rotational constant. We have a 1/4.

And so this is 1/4 times
these operate, 1/4 times

the difference. And here we're going to have
the sum of rotational constants.

And these are the
same two b plus c.
Here is a.

So we can see how this
is going to be written. And what we're going
to do is we're going
to call this b plus c over 2.

And we're going to
multiply that by 4.

AUDIENCE: In the Hamiltonian,
that first squared sign should be inside the
parentheses, right?
PROFESSOR: Which squared sign? AUDIENCE: j squared minus jz.
PROFESSOR: Oh, absolutely.

OK, and so we're going
to have 1 over 2ix
plus 1 over 2iy jj plus 1.

So these are the
diagonal elements. And so this is--
is going to be b plus c over 2. We got the 2 over here.

And this is going to be
a minus b plus c over 2 a
over 2 minus b plus c over 2.

And then we have the
off diagonal terms. Now, in the oblate
limit, instead

of having b plus c over 2, we're
going to have a plus b over 2.

In both cases, we
call this b bar.

Because we want to close
our eyes and think this is like a diatomic molecule or
this is like a symmetric top.

And so we want the
notation to guide us. OK, and the off
diagonal elements

will be of the form jkh
rotation jk plus or minus 2.

And they will be 1/4 in this
case for the prolate limit

b minus c then jj plus
1 minus kj plus or minus

1 [INAUDIBLE] jk plus 1
minus k plus or minus 1 k
plus or minus 2 square.

So again, we start with k. We go from k to k
plus or minus 1.

And then we go from k plus or
minus 1 to k plus or minus 2. And we always have
in here the product

of the initial and
final values of k.

OK, so that's the Hamiltonian
for an asymmetric top.

We have the asymmetry,
the stuff that is new,

which is related
to the difference in rotational constants. And we have the stuff that's old
as the average of the two non--

we always distinguish the
near symmetry axis, the a, from the b and c. So we take the average of
the two non-special guys.

And then we have this. And this looks just
like the symmetric top. And so all of the
corrections are

due to the difference between
the two non-special rotational constants.

AUDIENCE: So does that mean for
every asymmetric top molecule one could imagine some special
symmetric top molecule that

has the same properties with
particular arbitrary constants?

PROFESSOR: Well, you can
imagine the symmetric top that has the same a
and b as a and b bar.

AUDIENCE: Right. So how would this infer-- PROFESSOR: But the
energy levels--

you'll have asymmetry
splittings, which the symmetric top can't have. And so the energy levels
won't resemble each other,

except for the overall scale.  AUDIENCE: Like the
relative differences

between the first and
second transitions and the second and third-- PROFESSOR: No, between
the top and bottom k.

I think that you have
to find out what's

the same between the two. OK, so now, clearly,
we have something

that's telling you about the
strength of the asymmetry.

And it makes sense to compare
the strength of the asymmetry to the differences
between the levels

that you get from
the symmetric top.

So the k splittings
from the symmetric top

tell you how the molecule
is trying to preserve the symmetric top pattern.

And then you have this other
thing, which if it's small doesn't do much. If it's large, completely
destroys the pattern.

And so how do you decide on how
to measure the strength of b

minus c relative to a plus b? Well, you can do
perturbation theory.

You can say, OK,
let's just compare the off diagonal elements
k jk jk plus or minus

2 to the difference
in diagonal elements.

And so you do this. And there's a lot of
algebra that ensues.

And you get some
function of j and k.  And you get a minus c
over 2b minus a minus c.
So this is universal.

This is special to the molecule. This is the strength
of the asymmetry.

And now, suppose we say
we have a symmetric top.

In a symmetric prolate
top, b is equal to c.

So what does this become? That's the same
thing as a minus b.

And this is the same
thing as b minus a.
So this quantity is minus 1.

For an oblate top,
a is equal to b. And so if a is equal to
b, we can rewrite this
as b minus c over b minus c.

And this is plus 1. So this parameter goes
from minus 1 to plus 1

in the extreme limits. And it turns out
that actually what we use is the reciprocal of that.

Kappa is Ray's
asymmetry parameter.

Who is Ray? He wrote a paper in Z. Phys. AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE] PROFESSOR: And his
initials are S--
where is it?

Where is my-- BS Ray. He wrote his paper
in Z. Phys. in 1932.

And I'm sure you'll find it. Anyway, so the asymmetry
parameter is 2b minus a minus
c over a minus c.

So this is how big is
the off diagonal matrix

element relative to the
diagonal matrix element? And so when this is big,
it's very asymmetric.

So when the reciprocal is
near 0, it's very asymmetric.

We have a parameter that goes
